org.fluidity.composition.spi

Interface ComponentFactory


  • public interface ComponentFactory
    Creates instances of a component when mere constructor and field injection is not adequate.

    Note: Component factories expose an internal process to the external world and thus hard measures are taken to protect the former from the latter by wrapping sensitive functionality under highly focused interfaces.

    Component instantiation follows a certain protocol and ComponentFactory objects must follow that protocol to integrate well to Fluid Tools. This interface defines the necessary methods and interfaces for that integration.

    The protocol is as follows:

    • The ComponentFactory.resolve() method is invoked.
    • The receiver uses the provided container to discover and resolve the created component and its dependencies without actually instantiating any component, and returns a future instance of the created component.
    • The ComponentFactory.Instance.bind() method is invoked, at a later time, on the returned future component instance.

    Usage

    Basic Pattern

     @Component(api = MyComponent.class)
 final class MyComponentFactory implements ComponentFactory {

   public Instance resolve(final ComponentContext context, final Container dependencies) throws Exception {
     return dependencies.instance(MyComponentImpl.class);
   }
 }
 
     @Component(automatic = false)
 final class MyComponentImpl implements MyComponent {
   …
 }

    Context Adaptation

    Context adaption may be necessary when you need to pass some Fluid Tools context, collected from a list of qualifiers, to a component not managed by Fluid Tools. The basic mechanism is:
    • the factory collects the context qualifiers,
    • then passes them on directly as dependencies to the created component.
     @Component(api = CreatedComponent.class)
 @Component.Qualifiers(CustomQualifier.class)
 final class CustomFactory implements ComponentFactory {

   public Instance resolve(final ComponentContext context, final Container dependencies) throws Exception { {
     final CustomQualifier[] contexts = context.qualifiers(CustomQualifier.class);

     return dependencies.instance(CreatedComponent.class, registry -> {
       registry.bindInstance(contexts, CustomQualifier[].class);
       registry.bindComponent(CreatedComponent.class);
     });
   }
 }
 
     public final class CreatedComponent {

   CreatedComponent(final CustomQualifier[] contexts) {
     …
   }
 }
    For more examples, see the resolve(ComponentContext, Container) method.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static interface  ComponentFactory.Bindings
      Bindings for a component created by a ComponentFactory.
      static interface  ComponentFactory.Container
      A ComponentFactory.Resolver that can create local resolvers.
      static interface  ComponentFactory.Instance
      Represents a future component instance created by a ComponentFactory.
      static interface  ComponentFactory.Registry
      Registry to bind components to by a ComponentFactory.
      static interface  ComponentFactory.Resolver
      Container to resolve dependencies of some component to be created by the component factory.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ComponentFactory.Instance resolve(ComponentContext context, ComponentFactory.Container dependencies)
      Resolves and discovers the dependencies of the component created by this factory.

    • Method Detail

      • resolve

        ComponentFactory.Instance resolve(ComponentContext context,
                                  ComponentFactory.Container dependencies)
                           throws Exception
        Resolves and discovers the dependencies of the component created by this factory. Actual component instantiation will only take place when bind is invoked on the returned object.

        The static dependencies of the component are discovered by calls to methods of the dependencies argument, the simplest of which are instance(Class) and instance(Class, Bindings).

        More elaborate factory logic may require acquisition of a resolver via ComponentFactory.Container.resolver(), ComponentFactory.Container.resolver(Class), or ComponentFactory.Container.resolver(Class, ComponentFactory.Bindings), and then calls to discover(Class) to resolve dependencies of specific component classes, and even more elaborate cases may require other, more specific, calls to ComponentFactory.Resolver.

        The ComponentFactory.Instance.bind() method of the returned object will be invoked, at the appropriate time, to actually bind the created component, and its local, internal dependencies to a container. Actual instantiation should, when possible at all, be left to the caller of that method. If the factory absolutely has to instantiate the component on account of, for instance, having to call an external factory, then that instantiation should only take place in ComponentFactory.Instance.bind().

        Usage

        The ComponentFactory shows the basic pattern of the implementation.

        The following code snippet shows the pattern of the implementation in case it has to call the component's constructor: 

         public Instance resolve(final ComponentContext context, final Container dependencies) throws Exception {
   final Resolver resolver = dependencies.resolver(CreatedComponent.class);
   final Constructor<?> constructor = resolver.constructor(CreatedComponent.class);
   final Dependency<?>[] arguments = resolver.resolve(constructor);

   // make sure the assumptions implicit in the code below
   // are not broken by changes to MyComponentImpl:
   if (false) {
     final MyComponent result = new CreatedComponent((Dependency1) null,
                                                     (Dependency2) null,
                                                     (String) null,
                                                     0);
   }

   arguments[2] = resolver.constant("some text");
   arguments[3] = resolver.constant(5);

   return Instance.of(CreatedComponent.class,
                      registry -> registry.bindInstance(constructor.newInstance(resolver.instantiate(arguments))));
 }

        The following code snippet shows the pattern of the implementation in case it has to call some external factory: 

         public Instance resolve(final ComponentContext context, final Container dependencies) throws Exception {

   // make sure the assumptions implicit in the code below
   // are not broken by changes to ExternalLibrary:
   if (false) {
     final MyComponent result = external.factoryMethod((Dependency1) null,
                                                       (Dependency2) null,
                                                       (String) null,
                                                       (Integer) null);
   }

   final Method method = external.getClass().getMethod("factoryMethod",
                                                       Dependency1.class,
                                                       Dependency2.class,
                                                       String.class,
                                                       int.class);

   final Resolver resolver = dependencies.resolver(external.getClass());
   final Dependency<?>[] arguments = resolver.resolve(external.getClass(), method);

   arguments[2] = resolver.constant("some text");
   arguments[3] = resolver.constant(5);

   return Instance.of(method.getReturnedType(),
                      registry -> registry.bindInstance(resolver.invoke(external.getClass(), method, arguments)));
 }
        See Methods.get(Class, Methods.Selector) to see how you can get an interface method in a refactoring friendly manner.
        Parameters:
        context - the context under which component creation will take place. This context contains only those annotations that this factory lists in its @Component.Qualifiers annotation.
        dependencies - the dependency resolver to notify of any dependencies the created class will have.
        Returns:
        an object that will bind the created components and its dependencies, or null if no component will be instantiated.
        Throws:
        Exception - when an error occurs.
